after.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: when a particular event or time has happened, or when someone has done something
after.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: After the war many soldiers stayed in France.
I go swimming every day after work.
Do you believe in life after death?
The first attack started just after midnight.
David went to bed straight after (=immediately after) supper.
After you’d called the police, what did you do?
Zimmerman changed his name after he left Germany.
People still remember the 1958 revolution and what came after (=happened after it).
Ten years after he bought the painting, Carswell discovered that it was a fake.
two days/three weeks etc after (something)
His car was outside your house the morning after Bob’s engagement party.
the day/week/year etc after (something)
I’ll see you again tomorrow or the day after.
the day/week/year etc after (something)
She retired from politics the year after she received the Nobel Prize.
the day/week/year etc after (something)
Not long after the wedding, his wife became ill.
soon/not long/shortly after (something)
The family moved to Hardingham in June 1983, and Sarah’s first child was born soon after.
soon/not long/shortly after (something)
After leaving school, Mackay worked in a restaurant for a year.
after doing something
after.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: when a particular amount of time has passed
after.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: After ten minutes remove the cake from the oven.
You’ll get used to it after a while.
After months of negotiation, an agreement was finally reached.
after.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: following someone or something else in a list or a piece of writing, or in order of importance
after.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Whose name is after yours on the list?
The date should be written after the address.
After football, tennis is my favourite sport.
The UK is the world’s third largest arms producer, after the USA and Russia.
after.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: used when telling the time to say how many minutes have passed since a particular hour
after.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The movie starts at a quarter  (=fifteen minutes) after seven.
after.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: following someone in order to stop or speak to them
after.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: I heard someone running after me, and a voice called my name.
after.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: in the direction of someone who has just left
after.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: ‘Good luck, ’ she called after me as I left.
Harry stood in the doorway gazing after her.
after.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: when someone has left a place or has finished doing something
after.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Remember to close the door after you.
I spend all day cleaning up after the kids.
after.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: because of something that happened earlier
after.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: I’m not surprised he walked out, after the way she treated him.
After your letter, I didn’t think I’d ever see you again.
after.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: in spite of something that was done in the past
after.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: How can you treat me like this after all I’ve done for you?
after.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: when you have passed a particular place or travelled a certain distance along a road
after.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: After a mile you will come to a crossroads.
after.translation[0].definitions[10].def: used to say who or what first had the name that someone or something has been given
after.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: His name is Alessandro, after his grandfather.
It was named Waterloo Bridge, after the famous battle.
after.translation[0].definitions[11].def: in the same style as a particular painter, musician etc
after.translation[0].definitions[12].def: used to say politely that someone else can use or do something before you do
after.translation[0].definitions[13].def: used to ask someone if you can have or use something after they have finished
after.translation[0].definitions[13].exa: After you with that knife, please.
after.translation[0].note_box[0].section: after
after something happens, or after a period of time has passed. After is used especially when talking about the past
We went for a walk after lunch.
After an hour, we got tired of waiting and went home.
They got married just after Christmas.
in
after a particular period of time. In is used especially when talking about the future, especially the next few minutes, hours, days etc
The concert’s due to start in a few minutes.
I’ll come back in an hour.
In a few years’ time, this place will look completely different.
within
after less than a month, two weeks etc has passed – used especially when the time seems surprisingly short
He developed a headache at lunchtime, and within two hours he was dead.
Within two days of arriving she had managed to upset everyone.
24 hours/a year etc from now
at a time 24 hours, a year etc after now
A week from now we’ll be in Paris.
afterwards
after an event or time you have mentioned
Jones admitted afterwards that she had been very nervous during the game.
Speaking to reporters afterward, he said the operation had been a success.
He moved to Belgium, and soon afterwards he met Angela.
later
some time after now or after the time you are talking about
I’ll tell you about it later when I’m less busy.
James went off, and came back ten minutes later with some food.
subsequently
after something had happened in the past
The book was published in 1954 and was subsequently translated into fifteen languages.
after.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: in the back part of a boat or an aircraft
